title: The Temptation and Ministry of Jesus
shortSummary: Matthew chapter 4 details the temptation of Jesus by the devil in the wilderness, demonstrating His obedience and reliance on Scripture. It also marks the beginning of His public ministry, including His call of the first disciples and His healing and teaching throughout Galilee.
timeline: c. AD 27-29 - Beginning of Jesus' public ministry after His baptism

keyCharacters.name: Jesus
keyCharacters.description: The Son of God who is led by the Spirit into the wilderness, resists temptation, begins His public ministry, calls disciples, and heals the sick.

keyCharacters.name: The Devil
keyCharacters.description: The tempter who challenges Jesus in the wilderness, attempting to divert Him from His divine mission.

keyCharacters.name: Simon Peter
keyCharacters.description: One of the first disciples called by Jesus, a fisherman who leaves his nets to follow Him.

keyCharacters.name: Andrew
keyCharacters.description: Brother of Simon Peter and one of the first disciples called by Jesus, also a fisherman.

keyCharacters.name: James and John
keyCharacters.description: Sons of Zebedee, called by Jesus to leave their fishing business and follow Him.

definitions.definition: A test or trial designed to entice someone to sin or disobey God.
The voluntary abstaining from food for spiritual purposes, here lasting forty days and nights.
The reign and rule of God, both a present spiritual reality and a future fulfillment.
To turn away from sin and turn toward God with a changed heart and mind.
A Jewish place of worship and teaching where Jesus preached during His ministry.

outline.heading: The Temptation of Jesus
outline.description: Jesus is led by the Spirit into the wilderness where He fasts for forty days and nights. The devil tempts Him three times, but Jesus resists each temptation by quoting Scripture, affirming His obedience to God and His mission.

outline.heading: Jesus Begins His Ministry in Galilee
outline.description: After hearing of John the Baptist’s imprisonment, Jesus moves to Galilee fulfilling Isaiah’s prophecy. He begins preaching the message of repentance because the kingdom of heaven is near.

outline.heading: The Calling of the First Disciples
outline.description: Jesus calls Simon Peter, Andrew, James, and John to leave their fishing trade and follow Him, promising to make them 'fishers of men,' indicating their new mission to gather souls.

outline.heading: Jesus’ Ministry of Teaching, Preaching, and Healing
outline.description: Jesus travels throughout Galilee teaching in synagogues, preaching the gospel of the kingdom, and healing all kinds of sickness and diseases. His fame spreads, and large crowds follow Him from various regions.

application: Rely on Scripture to resist temptation and remain obedient to God in times of trial.
Respond promptly and faithfully to Jesus’ call in your life, leaving behind what hinders your spiritual growth.
Preach repentance and the nearness of God’s kingdom in your daily life as a testimony to others.
Trust in Jesus’ power to heal and restore, bringing physical and spiritual wholeness.

keyVerses.text: But he answered and said, It is written, Man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that proceedeth out of the mouth of God.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights Jesus’ reliance on Scripture as the true sustenance for life, emphasizing spiritual nourishment over physical needs.

keyVerses.text: From that time Jesus began to preach, and to say, Repent: for the kingdom of heaven is at hand.
keyVerses.significance: Marks the beginning of Jesus’ public ministry and the urgent call to repentance in light of God’s imminent kingdom.

keyVerses.text: And he saith unto them, Follow me, and I will make you fishers of men.
keyVerses.significance: Jesus’ invitation to discipleship includes a new mission to reach others with the gospel, illustrating the transformative call to Christian service.

keyVerses.text: And Jesus went about all Galilee, teaching in their synagogues, and preaching the gospel of the kingdom, and healing all manner of sickness and all manner of disease among the people.
keyVerses.significance: Demonstrates the comprehensive nature of Jesus’ ministry—teaching, preaching, and healing—as a fulfillment of Messianic prophecy.
